text: mr. Bradshaw good morning and you
tweeted yesterday that the Labour Shadow
Cabinet must act now to save the parties
this the action that you want to see
well I think it was in the early hours
of this morning when this extraordinary
news came through in the middle of the
night I mean it does seem to me to be
absolutely extraordinary thing to do
when our country is going through this
period of huge uncertainty to sack
you're probably most respected and most
experienced frontbencher who's also shed
shadow foreign secretary who will have a
incredibly important role in the next
month's holding the government to
account on the renegotiation but also
facing a possible probable general
election in the autumn one of our best
performers best communicators are no
longer in the front line it's very very
sad I want to pick up on that note from
our political editor there that half of
the shadow cabinet expected to resign
this morning what do you know and can
you name names who is expected to resign
I don't know about that you'll have to
ask them but I do think following the
absolutely catastrophic defeat for
labour in the referendum campaign a
campaign that the Jeremy led sort of are
and the prospect of a an autumn election
we really do need to think very
carefully in the Labor Party where the
Jeremy is the person who can take us
into that election and win it as well as
the person who for the next days and
weeks I can do the right job in helping
steer britain as opposition leader
through this very very dangerous period
how damaging is this instability we we
look at the Conservative Party looking
for a new prime minister looking for a
new leader clearly they're in the labour
party also now this unrest how damaging
is it for everybody else that there is
no one taking control here well I think
it's very unsettling for people I think
the public are bewildered by the
aftermath of the referendum result I've
talked to quite a lot of people in my
own constituency who voted leave who now
regret it
a lot of labour members who supported
and voted for Jeremy in the leadership
who are angry at his lack of leadership
in the
pain and there's no real leadership in
the country at the moment and we need
that we need it both in government but
critically we need it in our main
opposition party this is probably the
most tumultuous period in our recent
history and we need politicians who are
leaders who are competent are who the
public can trust and have confidence in
and as I say if as is likely we are
going to face a general election in just
a few months time the Labour Party has
to ask itself a very very serious
question about whether Jeremy is the
person who can win us that election and
lead us through this very perilous time
yeah and whether he is the person to win
that election but remember at the same
time he has massive support from the
Labour Party activists and the
grassroots support I'm interested in
that disconnect that disconnect between
party officials and the rest of the
party how you ever get unity well he had
that about a year ago but I have to say
in the wake of this referendum result
everything in our country has changed
and as I just said Ben I spoke to a lot
of Labour Party supporters and members
in my constituency here in Exeter over
the weekend who supported Jeremy who now
do not think he is the right person to
take us forward in turn into an autumn
election because the likelihood would be
if he's there as leader that we will
lose scores of seats will be wiped out
and that's not a prospect that any any
of us wants it's not a prospect that
very good for the country the country at
this time needs a strong and competent
center-left
opposition party because of the
uncertainty that you just referred to
